stream_context.summary: Bonus Christmas-week stream focused on building two areas.  Kaze first finalised star names and a music-synced intro cut-scene for “Oily Boily Bay”, then returned to block-out and collision work on the new Wild-West world (working titles: “Wild West Valley / Cowboy Canyon”).  Work included layout of buildings, giant set-piece props, and colour-coded warp-pipes used as shortcuts.

development_findings.summary: Wild-West world will contain a frontier town (milk bar, Koopa bank, sheriff’s jail, windmills, train) plus a secondary ‘surreal canyon’ section with oversized props (giant shotgun, wheel, skull, hoof-iron).  A scavenger-hunt star uses signs that send the player between these landmarks.  Four colour-coded warp-pipes connect the areas for flow.
development_findings.quote: “Mario’s goal in this area is gonna be to find the treasure… the first hint might be something like inside the big skull… the pipes will lead to each other as shortcuts.”

development_findings.summary: RTYI will keep the original Mario 64 structure of 15 main courses but with much larger individual levels.
Kaze enforces a hard 64 MB ROM limit so the hack fits on stock N64 cartridges; going larger would feel like “cheating”.
development_findings.quote: “One of my conditions is that it fits on a normal N64 cartridge. I’m not going to go above 64 megabytes.”

development_findings.summary: Intro cut-scene for Oily Boily Bay was built using three camera splines timed precisely to the level music’s drum beats; Kaze iterated frame counts to hit musical cues.
development_findings.quote: “The most important part of the cutscene for me is that it’s fitting to the music.”

development_findings.summary: Technical pipeline: Blender → Fast64 plug-in → N64 model format.  Kaze created new low-poly pipes with CI8 textures, one-cycle materials, and custom geo-layout code that changes colour via bparams.
Uses NEMU64 for debugging on PC, original hardware for accuracy; refuses to adopt Parallel Launcher despite viewer pressure.
development_findings.quote: “Parallel Launcher tards can’t just let me not use Parallel Launcher in peace.”

context_findings.summary: Design philosophy: after playing SpongeBob BFBB, Kaze believes a friction-free, in-offensive platformer with simple objectives would be hugely popular.
context_findings.quote: “Games are just so goddamn bad that if you make a game that is just not offensive to the player… people will love it.”

context_findings.summary: Visible frustration when chat repeatedly suggests tools he dislikes; likens the experience to ‘Squidward Annoy Day’.
Payment issues: PayPal locked his account, preventing him from paying Biobak; he dislikes using crypto because of fees and tax complications.
context_findings.quote: “I want to pay Biobak with paper money but PayPal is not letting me… I’d literally rather send him a bank transfer.”

context_findings.summary: Maintains ethical stance against predatory monetisation and applauds new Chinese regulations banning gacha for minors.
Notices rising viewer numbers after dual-streaming to YouTube and Twitch; considers it a possible marketing boost.

biobak.summary: Tasked with finishing several unfinished areas (underground of Oily Boily Bay and canyon interiors).  Awaiting payment due to Kaze’s PayPal issues.
biobak.quote: “Biobak said he would finish this area… I still need to pay Biobak and PayPal is not letting me.”

biobak.summary: Previously supplied the base pipe model Kaze modified for today’s work.

badub.summary: Composes music for all new levels ‘nowadays’; created the Wild-West track used on stream.
badub.quote: “Who made the music for this level? Badub. He always makes the music for my levels nowadays at least.”

badub.summary: A new track is still needed for parts of Oily Boily Bay.

zeina.summary: Currently modelling a giant skull prop for the Wild-West level; Kaze praised an in-progress screenshot.
zeina.quote: “Oh, that looks really good, Zeina. I like that a lot.”

zeina.summary: Acts as informal tester and domestic support (prepared schnitzel, gave holiday gifts).

key_stories.title: PayPal Lock-out
key_stories.summary: Kaze cannot pay lead artist Biobak because PayPal froze his account, halting progress on assets.  He is reluctant to use cryptocurrency due to fees and tax headaches, and wishes for a simple bank transfer.
key_stories.process: Considered crypto work-around, vented frustrations on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Still unresolved; asset delivery from Biobak uncertain.
key_stories.key_quote: I still need to buy crypto just to pay Biobak and then he has to pay crypto fees too.

key_stories.title: Parallel Launcher Meltdown
key_stories.summary: Viewers kept insisting Kaze switch to Parallel Launcher.  He tried again live, hit immediate controller and display issues, and erupted into a comedic rant, vowing to become its ‘number one hater’.
key_stories.challenge: Community pressure to adopt a tool that doesn’t work on his setup.
key_stories.process: Attempted live test; consulted original dev previously; repeated failures.
key_stories.outcome: Swore off the emulator, reaffirmed commitment to NEMU64/hardware.
key_stories.key_quote: Parallel Launcher tards can’t just let me not use Parallel Launcher in peace.

key_stories.title: Colour-Coded Warp Pipes
key_stories.summary: Needed fast navigation across sprawling canyon.  Kaze designed four warp pipes, each with distinct colours that respect N64 one-cycle limitations and even considered colour-blind readability.
key_stories.challenge: Create shortcuts without breaking aesthetic or performance limits.
key_stories.process: Modelled new low-poly pipe, iterated textures and HSV values, discussed material cycles, tested for crashes, fixed assembly bug.
key_stories.outcome: Working set of four pipes now links key landmarks.
key_stories.key_quote: These pipes look so good now—what the fuck.

key_stories.title: Music-Synced Intro Cut-scene
key_stories.summary: Oily Boily Bay lacked an opening. Kaze plotted three camera splines and meticulously adjusted frame counts to land on drum beats.
key_stories.challenge: Make an engaging cut-scene that feels musical yet runs on real hardware.
key_stories.process: Iterated spline lengths, used emulator to preview, matched visual landmarks with audio cues.
key_stories.outcome: Cut-scene approved; to be integrated with star 1 of the course.
key_stories.key_quote: The cutscene has to change exactly when the music changes.
